sections.summary: The 'Range Finder'. Stochastics compares a closing price to its price range over a period. It works best in flat, sideways markets. It tells you where the price is relative to its recent high-low channel.
sections.deep_dive: %K is the fast line, %D is the slow line. A crossover in the overbought (>80) or oversold (<20) zone is the classic signal. It is faster and more sensitive than RSI, but prone to false signals.
sections.council_debate: {"geopolitics": "In a range-bound geopolitical standoff (no war, no peace), Stochastics is king. It captures the back-and-forth headlines perfectly. Buy the dip at 20, sell the rip at 80.", "macro": "Macro trends destroy Stochastics users. In a strong inflation uptrend, Stochastics will stay > 80 forever. If you short every time it hits 80, you will be wiped out. Use it only when the Macro is neutral.", "quant": "We use Stochastics for 'Mean Reversion' in Asian trading hours (often low volatility). If the S&P 500 futures dip to Stoch 10 during the Asian lunch break, our bots buy it for a quick bounce back to 50.", "technical": "Look for the 'Hinge'. When %K and %D lines flatten out and then sharply turn, it looks like a door hinge. This visual pattern often precedes a violent breakout from the range.", "policy": "Central banks pegging rates creates perfect Stochastic ranges. If the Fed says 'Rates will stay 5.25% for a year', the bond market becomes a Stochastics playground. Buy low yield, sell high yield.", "tech": "In Crypto, Stochastics is useful for 'Scalping' on the 15-minute chart. Crypto ranges are wide (5-10%). Capturing the swing from 20 to 80 on a 15m chart is a profitable strat for day traders."}
sections.forecast_risks: Pop and Drop. In a crash, Stochastics will hit 0 and stay there. Buying because 'it can't go lower' is a fallacy. It can 'embed' at 0 for the entire duration of the crash.
sections.gms_conclusion: Use Stochastics in Boxes (Ranges). Use MACD in Trends. Know which environment you are in.
